questions.text: Solid wastes generally should not contain:
questions.solution:
Solid wastes should not contain nightsoil, which is untreated human waste (feces).

Solid wastes generally contain:

  • Garbage (food wastes)
  • Rubbish waste (papers, plastics, etc.)
  • Demolition products (bricks, masonry, etc.)
  • Sewage treatment residue
  • Dead animals and other waste materials

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of solid waste or refuse disposal?
questions.solution:
Oxidation ponds are not used for solid waste or refuse disposal. It is used for sewage treatment.

Methods of solid waste disposal are:

  • Dumping
  • Controlled tipping
  • Incineration
  • Composting
  • Manure pits
  • Burial

questions.text: Which of the following is the most insanitary method of waste disposal?
questions.solution:
The most insanitary method of waste disposal is dumping.

Methods of waste disposal include:

  • Controlled tipping or sanitary landfill - Most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available
  • Incineration - Method of choice where suitable land is not available
  • Composting
  • Manure pits
  • Burial
  • Dumping

questions.text: Which method is most appropriate when suitable land for waste disposal is available?
questions.solution:
Controlled tipping is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal when suitable land is available.

In this method, waste materials are placed in a trench, compacted, and covered with earth at the end of the day. This method is also called a sanitary landfill. Chemical, bacteriological and physical changes occur in the buried refuse with temperatures rising to over 60 degrees Celsius within 7 days.

Methods used for controlled tipping are:

  • Trench method
  • Ramp method
  • Area method

Sewage farming is also a method of sewage disposal in places where sufficient and suitable land is available. It is also called land treatment or broad irrigation.

questions.text: In controlled tipping, the amount of land required for the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000 is:
questions.solution:
In controlled tipping, one acre of land is required by the trench method to be practiced for a population of 10,000.

It is also known as a sanitary landfill. It is the most satisfactory method of refuse disposal where suitable land is available. In this method, waste material is placed in a trench or other prepared area. Then, it is adequately compacted and covered with earth at the end of the day.

Methods used in controlled tipping are:

  • Trench method: Done in places where level ground is available
  • Ramp method: Well suited where the terrain is moderately sloping
  • Area method: Used for filling land depressions, disused quarries, and clay pits

questions.text: Which of the following is false about composting?

choices.text: Bangalore method is an aerobic process
Mechanical composting uses a controlled environment
Nightsoil can also be disposed with composting
Compost has few or no disease-causing pathogens

questions.solution:
The Bangalore method of composting is an anaerobic process.

Composting is a method of combined disposal of refuse and nightsoil. In this process, organic matter is broken down into compost. It has manure value and few or no disease-causing pathogens.

Bangalore method is an anaerobic method and is also called hot fermentation process. Trenches with a depth of not more than 90cm are used for this. This is done by spreading a layer of refuse (15 cm thick) at the bottom of the trench and nightsoil (5cm thick) is added next. Layers of refuse and nightsoil are added alternatively till the heap rises to 30cm above ground level. The heap is then covered with excavated earth. At the end of 4 – 6 months, decomposition will be completed.

Mechanical composting is an aerobic process. In this method, compost is manufactured on a large scale by processing raw materials and turning out a finished product. The refuse is first cleared of salvageable materials. It is then pulverised to reduce the size of particles to less than 2 inches. The pulverised refuse is then mixed with sewage, sludge or nightsoil in a rotating machine and incubated.

questions.text: All of the following are methods of disposing only excreta except:
questions.solution:
Bangalore method, also known as the hot fermentation process, is a form of composting that is used for disposing of both solid waste and nightsoil (excreta).

Methods of excreta disposal:

  • Unsewered areas:
    • Service type latrines (conservancy system) - In this, nightsoil is collected manually from pail or bucket type latrines and then disposed of by burying or composting
    • Non-service type latrines (sanitary latrines)
      • Borehole latrine
      • Dug well or pit latrine
      • Water-seal latrines – Examples are P.R.A.I. type, R.C.A. type, and Sulabh shauchalaya
      • Septic tanks
      • Aqua privy
    • Latrines for camps and temporary use
      • Shallow and deep trench latrine
      • Pit latrine
      • Borehole latrine
  • Sewered areas:
    • Water carriage system and sewage treatment 
      • Primary treatment – Screening, removal of grit and plain sedimentation
      • Secondary treatment – Trickling filters, activated sludge process
      • Other methods – sea and river outfalls, sewage farming, oxidation ponds

questions.text: Which of the following is the oldest non-service type of latrines in India?
questions.solution:
The oldest non-service type of latrines in India is the borehole latrine. It was introduced in the 1930s to combat hookworm infections.

Special equipment called auger is used to dig a borehole latrine.

Advantages:

  • No special staff is needed for upkeep as after using the latrine is closed and another hole is dug elsewhere
  • Breeding of flies is less
  • No water pollution if located far from a water source

Demerits:

  • Fills up rapidly
  • Augers are not readily available
  • Water pollution is still a risk

questions.text: There is an outbreak of hookworm infection in your locality. On investigation, it is found that the outbreak is a result of open-air defecation. The district council decides to construct an RCA type of latrine in every household.  What is the optimum water seal required?
questions.solution:
The optimum water seal required for an RCA type of latrine is 2 – 2.5 cm.

It was designed by the Research-cum-Action Projects (RCA) in Environmental Sanitation of the Ministry of Health. Water seals aids in preventing flies and other organisms from reaching the waste. It also prevents the escape of odors and foul gases, eliminating the nuisance from the smell.

Features of RCA type of latrine
Location More than 15m away from the water source
Squatting plate Should be impervious and should allow for drainage of water
Pan Receives the nightsoil, urine, and washes water.
Trap Holds the water and provides the water seal. A good trap has an effective seal of around 2 – 2.5 cms.
Connecting pipe Present in indirect type and absent in direct type
Dug well Has to be changed after it is filled
Superstructure Built for privacy and shelter

questions.text: A health committee formed under Swachh Bharat Mission is involved in constructing septic tanks in every household. Which of the following is true about a septic tank?
questions.solution:
The recommended retention period for a septic tank is 24 hours.

If the retention period is too short, there is insufficient treatment of sewage and if it is too long, then undue septicity results.

There are single and double-chambered septic tanks. The minimum capacity recommended for a septic tank is 500 gallons. The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.

Related Pearl: Septic Tank

  • It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment.
  • Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.
  • Design features:
    • There are single and double chambered septic tanks.
    • The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household.
    • The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.
    • The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
    • The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m.
    • The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover.
    • Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.
  • Working:
    • Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface
    • Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time
    • Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank
    • By these processes, sewage is purified
  • Operation and maintenance:
    • Soap water and phenols must not be used
    • Desludging must be done at least once a year

questions.text: What is wastewater without human excreta called?
questions.solution:
Wastewater that doesn’t contain human excreta is called sullage. It is also called greywater. E.g., waste water from the kitchen.

Sewage is wastewater from a community that contains solid and liquid excreta along with street and yard washings. It is also called blackwater.

questions.text: What is the average amount of sewage which flows though the sewerage system in 24 hours known as?
questions.solution: The average amount of sewage which flows though the sewerage system in 24 hours is known as dry weather flow.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used to express the strength of sewage?
questions.solution:
E. coli count is not used to express the strength of sewage.

The strength of sewage is expressed only in terms of:

  • Biochemical oxygen demand
  • Chemical oxygen demand
  • Suspended solids

Related Pearl: Strength of Sewage

The strength of sewage is expressed by the following.

  • Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD):
    • It is the standard test which is an indicator of the organic content of sewage
    • It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage during a specified period (generally 5 days), at a specified temperature (generally 20 deg.C) for the aerobic destruction or use of organic matter by living microorganisms.
    • A high BOD (300 mg/l) indicates a high content of easily degradable, organic material while a low BOD (100mg/l) indicates the presence of content that is not easily degradable, low volume of organic matter or measurement problems.
  • Chemical oxygen demand (COD):
    • This test measures the oxygen equivalent of that portion of the organic matter in a sample that is susceptible to oxidation by a strong chemical oxidizer
    • This is mostly used when sewage contains toxic wastes
  • Suspended solids:
    • The amount of suspended solids in sewage may vary from 100 to 500 ppm (mg/litre)
    • If the level of suspended solids is 100 ppm, then sewage is weak and if it is more than 500 ppm, sewage is strong.

questions.solution:
Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) indicates the organic content of sewage.

It is defined as the amount of oxygen absorbed by a sample of sewage for aerobic destruction by living microorganisms.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the primary treatment of sewage?
questions.solution:
Aeration tank is not a part of primary treatment of sewage. It is a part of secondary treatment of sewage.

Related Pearl: Modern Sewage Treatment

Primary treatment:

  • Screening
    • A large metal screen is used to intercept large floating objects like dead animals, wood, rags, etc., so as to prevent clogging
  • Grit chamber
    • It is also called detritus chamber
    • It allows for the settlement of heavier solids like gravel or sand and permits the organic matter to flow through
    • The grit that is collected at the bottom is then disposed of
  • Primary sedimentation
    • In a primary sedimentation tank, sewage is allowed to flow slowly so that suspended matter that sediments form sludge which is then removed
    • Biological action takes place here and breaks down complex organic solids
    • Scum in the form of grease and fat collects on top of the tank
    • Sometimes, chemicals like lime are added to the effluent to enhance precipitation

Secondary treatment:

The effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is subjected to aerobic oxidation by trickling filter method or activated sludge process.

  • Trickling filter method
    • The trickling or percolating filter is a bed of crushed stones or clinker
    •  Effluent from the primary sedimentation tank is spread over the filter bed and as it percolates through it, it gets oxidized by bacterial flora. There is no actual filtration that occurs.
    • The oxidized sewage forms a light green material called humus. It is then led into secondary sedimentation tanks.
  • Activated sludge process
    • The heart of the activated sludge process is the aeration tank
    • In these tanks, the effluent from primary sedimentation is mixed with activated or return sludge (sludge from the final settling tank) and is then exposed to aeration for 6 to 8 hours.
    • During aeration, organic matter is oxidized into carbon dioxide, nitrates and water with the help of aerobic bacteria in the activated sludge.
  • Secondary sedimentation
    • From the trickling filters or aeration tanks, the oxidized sewage is allowed into a secondary sedimentation tank where it is held for 2 – 3 hours
    • Here, aerated sludge or activated sludge is formed, part of which is pumped back into an aeration tank
  • Sludge digestion
    • Sludge digestion can be done by incubating it under favourable conditions to allow anaerobic auto-digestion. This is done in sludge digestion tanks.
    • Disposal of sludge is also done by sea disposal
    • Sludge can also be disposed of by composting with solid refuse
  • Disposal of effluent
    • Disposal of effluent can be done by dilution in water bodies which has to then be chlorinated
    • Disposal on land is possible if the effluent can be used for irrigation purposes

questions.text: What is the function of the grit chamber in modern sewage treatment plants?

choices.text: Allow anaerobic auto-digestion of organic matter

questions.solution:
The function of the grit chamber in modern sewage treatment plants is to allow heavier particles in the sewage to settle.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a requirement for an oxidation pond?
questions.solution:
Aeration is not a requirement for an oxidation pond.

Oxidation ponds are also called waste stabilization ponds or redox ponds or sewage lagoons. They have become a popular method of purifying sewage for small communities. It is usually an open, shallow pool of around 1 – 1.5m depth with an inlet and outlet.

Requisites for an oxidation pond include:

  • Algae
  • Saprophytic bacteria
  • Sunlight 

All of the above factors help in the treatment of sewage waste through aerobic and anaerobic processes. The effluent formed can be used for land irrigation or can be forwarded for further treatment.
